title: What is the mass in grams of H₂ that can be formed from 56.4 grams of NH₃ in the following reaction? 2 NH₃(g) → 3 H₂(g) + N₂(g) - Quora

response.answer_text: Balanced equation 2NH₃(g) → 3H₂(g) + N₂(g) Calculate the moles of NH₃ in 56.4 g. moles (n) = mass (m)/molar mass (M) M(NH₃) = 14.007 g/mol N + (3 × 1.008 g/mol H) = 17.031 g NH₃/mol NH₃ m(NH₃) = 56.4 g NH₃ n(NH₃) = 56.4 g NH₃/17.031 g NH₃/mol NH₃ = 3.3116 mol NH₃ Use stoichiometry to calculate the moles of H₂ that can be produced by 3.3116 mol NH₃ , using the mole ratio between NH₃ and H₂ in the balanced equation. 3.3116 mol NH₃ × 3 mol H₂/2 mol NH₃ = 4.9674 mol H₂ Calculate the mass of 4.9674 mol H₂. m = n × M M(H₂) = 2 × 1.008 g/mol H = 2.016 g H₂/mol H₂ n(H₂) = 4.9674 mol H₂ × 2.016 g H₂/mol H₂ = 10.0 g H₂ to three significant figures The mass of H₂ that can be produced by the decomposition of 56.4 g of NH₃ is ≈ 10.0 g.
